entry.title: bitcoin DNS addresses
entry.summary: The email thread discusses the security implications of using DNSSEC for Bitcoin address communication. The concern is that in a coffee shop network, an attacker could claim that the requested zone is not DNSSEC signed and return their data, which most operating systems would not detect or prevent. While some operating systems do support DNSSEC, implementing a full resolver with root trust anchors and knowledge of root servers in Bitcoin may not be a good idea. The same attack can also apply to HTTPS with a self-signed certificate, where the A record is replaced by the attacker, and the request is sent to the attacker's server. The discussion highlights the need for simpler user experience in remembering and communicating a Bitcoin address. HTTPS is suggested as a better alternative to DNSSEC for Bitcoin address communication due to its several advantages without significant drawbacks.
